intro: Lupinus alopecuroides, commonly known as the Texas larkspur, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows to a height of 1 to 3 feet, featuring upright stems and clusters of blue to purple flowers. The plant has palmate leaves composed of 5 to 7 oval leaflets, and its flowers are spurred at the base, a characteristic feature of the Fabaceae family. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or sandy habitats. Lupinus alopecuroides is also valued for its ornamental appeal and is sometimes used in native plant gardens.
